Award.AwardTitle: Glaciers, Erosion, and Climate Change in the Himalaya Mountains
Award.AbstractNarration:
Erosion plays an important role in the development of the Himalaya Mountains, and is generally controlled by the interplay among tectonics, topography and climate that govern mountain building. Little is known, however, about rates of erosion at the heavily glaciarized crest of the range, and there is no consensus on whether glaciers accelerate or impede erosion in the region. This project will determine contemporary erosion rates for the Khumbu basin, at the foot of Mt Everest, through a detailed examination of the fluxes of ice and rock debris in this drainage basin. These fluxes will be determined on three time scales: during the 2-year duration of this project, ~60 years and ~10,000 years. Contemporary fluxes of ice and debris will be determined from analyses of digital topography and satellite images, existing glaciological and geomorphologic data, and field studies. These will reveal the debris advected with the ice and accumulating in the lower reaches of the glacier, and the debris that exits Khumbu Glacier through the proglacial stream. Mass balance and runoff will be modeled through the last six decades using available global climate data. Historical data documenting the glacier surface profile, surface velocities and debris cover will also guide modeled estimates of debris and ice fluxes through this period. Estimates will be made of the volume of the massive debris edifice that formed in the lower Khumbu valley since the last major glacial advance about 10,000 years ago to determine the volume of debris derived from the upper Khumbu basin. This will be accomplished using satellite imagery, digital elevation models, and available radar and gravity surveys. The erosion rate averaged over this time span can be calculated from this debris volume by accounting for the fraction of sediment evacuated fluvially during this period on the basis of the measurements of contemporary sediment flux in the Khumbu proglacial stream.

This study will advance knowledge of the interactions between snow and debris that sustain massive low-latitude glaciers and shape high mountains. Glaciers are common featues of mountain ranges around the world, and this study will document their role in erosion and mobilization of sediment. This project wiil also help evaluate two important issues: how climate change may affect glaciers in the Himalaya and the probable consequences for the vast population dependent on the major rivers that emanate from the glaciers in the Himalaya and Tibet. These consequences include 1) an initial increase in runoff due to the accelerated melting followed by diminishing supplies of fresh water from the dwindling glaciers, and 2) an increasing threat of floods from ice-dammed lakes formed by rapid glacier retreat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The greater Himalaya has the largest concentration of glaciers outside the polar ice sheets. Many glaciers are shrinking (Fig. 1), and disruption to the water supply will inevitably present challenges to the millions of people living downstream.

This study examines the interactions between snow and debris that sustain massive low latitude glaciers and shape high mountains, and it provides rich insights into the co-evolution and interdependence of valley glaciers and topography. Moreover, this research sheds new light on two timely and controversial issues: how global warming affects glaciers in the Himalaya and what the probable consequences are for the vast population dependent on the major rivers that emanate from the glaciers in the Himalaya and Tibet.  These consequences include 1) initial increase in runoff due to the accelerated melting followed by diminishing supplies of fresh water from the dwindling glaciers, 2) increasing threat of Glacial Outburst Floods from ice-dammed lakes formed by rapid glacier retreat, and 3) displacement of large populations currently living on coastal deltas in S.E. Asia due to sea-level rise. 

Erosion in the Himalaya has received considerable intellectual attention because of the important role erosion plays in the development of the range, and more generally, because of the broad interest in the rich interactions between tectonics, topography and climate that govern mountain building.  Little was known, however, about rates of erosion at the crest of the range that is largely covered with glaciers, and there was no consensus on whether glaciers accelerate or impede erosion in the region. Because of this major gap in knowledge, contradictory assumptions appear in the current literature about the role of glaciers and glaciations in shaping the Himalaya, and by inference, in other ranges that are or were largely eroded by glaciers.

A primary objective of our research was to determine contemporary erosion rates for the Khumbu basin, at the foot of Mt Everest, through a detailed examination of the fluxes of ice and rock debris in this drainage basin (Fig. 2). Recent scientific advances and an unusually rich, environmental database for this region made it possible to determine these fluxes on three time scales: the 3-year duration of this project, ~60 years and ~10,000 years.  We analyzed digital topography, satellite images, and a wealth of existing glaciological and geomorphologic data to determine the magnitude of glacier thinning on a decadal timescale (Fig. 2) and to guide our numerical models. In the field, we measured the ice motion and thickness of the debris mantling the glacier, the amount of debris moved with the ice and the amount that exits Khumbu Glacier through the proglacial stream (Fig. 3).  We also modeled numerically the contemporary dynamics of the glacier and its debris cover in the context of available data documenting the current motion, thickness and geometry of Khumbu Glacier and estimates of the mass balance and runoff through the last six decades derived from global climate data. 

To probe the longer term behavior of this glacier-debris system, we combined satellite multispectral image data, digital topography and ice-penetrating radar data (Fig. 4) to estimate the volume of the massive edifice of debris and ice that formed in the lower Khumbu valley since the last major glacial advance about 10,000 years ago.   From this we obtain the approximate volume of debris derived from the upper Khumbu basin, and hence the erosion rate, on this longer time scale.
